summary: **noun / cut-out remainder style.** A **jacket with a triangular or V-shaped notch clipped from a corner** to mark discounted or remainder stock.
definition: **noun / cut-out remainder style.** A **jacket with a triangular or V-shaped notch clipped from a corner** to mark discounted or remainder stock. Introduced by record labels in the 1960s as a physical defacement method to prevent promotional copies and overstock from being returned for full credit, the V-notch became a standard industry practice for marking cut-outs alongside corner clips and saw cuts. Typically punched or die-cut from the top right corner of the jacket spine, the notch permanently identifies the record as a budget or remainder item sold at reduced wholesale prices. Unlike drill holes that damage the vinyl itself, V-notches preserve playback quality while rendering the jacket non-returnable. Major labels employed different notch sizes and placements as internal tracking codes. Collectors generally view V-notch copies as less desirable than pristine originals, though the practice has become a nostalgic marker of 1970s-80s bargain bin culture. Modern reissue labels occasionally replicate the aesthetic ironically, while original cut-outs from classic albums remain affordable entry points for budget-conscious collectors seeking playable copies over investment-grade condition.
etymology: Derived from the distinctive V-shaped triangular cut used to mark remainder stock, distinguishing it from straight corner clips or saw cuts used by different distributors.
